Dialogue: Harry cleared his throat and then read, "The seven categories of movement are tied to the seven types of potion activators. These, of course, are animal, human, plant, mineral, crystalline, chemical, and other." The speed of movement further distinguishes the sub-category of activator. We've got ripples, so that's crystalline. It says... see page 517 for ripple speed..." he leafed ahead. "Here, so it looks like ours was kind of in the middle of the examples, which means it is one of the family of carbonates, hexates, or sul-in-ates?"
Reponse: "The headache potion uses powdered hugosilis vert as an activator, and that's a sulinate, so that's probably accurate," Hermione said.
title: A Stubbornly Persistent Illusion
author: ChokolatteJedi

Dialogue: "The headache potion uses powdered hugosilis vert as an activator, and that's a sulinate, so that's probably accurate," Hermione said.
Reponse: Harry looked at her blankly - they hadn't covered this potion in class yet, so he hadn't gotten to the part of the book that talked about crystalline families. "Trust me," Hermione said, and to her pleased surprise he just nodded and looked back at his book.
title: A Stubbornly Persistent Illusion
author: ChokolatteJedi

Dialogue: Harry looked at her blankly - they hadn't covered this potion in class yet, so he hadn't gotten to the part of the book that talked about crystalline families. "Trust me," Hermione said, and to her pleased surprise he just nodded and looked back at his book.
Reponse: "That's all I've got for starters."
title: A Stubbornly Persistent Illusion
author: ChokolatteJedi

Dialogue: "So if we really wanted to know what we were finding, we could get the first kind of parchment, and it would narrow it down for us, or the second to do the work for us?" Harry summarized.
Reponse: "Well, I'm sure the second one is hideously expensive," Hermione hedged. "For now, I think it is most important that we know our food or drink has been tainted, rather than needing to know exactly what is in it, beyond the general."
title: A Stubbornly Persistent Illusion
author: ChokolatteJedi

Dialogue: "Well, I'm sure the second one is hideously expensive," Hermione hedged. "For now, I think it is most important that we know our food or drink has been tainted, rather than needing to know exactly what is in it, beyond the general."
Reponse: "That's true," Harry shrugged. "So in general, we just need to make sure we can do the spells correctly, and ideally silently?"
title: A Stubbornly Persistent Illusion
author: ChokolatteJedi

Dialogue: "But there's time for that," Hermione said. "Now that we know that it works, we need to try it on the diluted vials so that we know how to recognize it in smaller quantities. And we need to practice the food one. Once we're sure we're doing it correctly, and can tell when we've got results, then it is a matter of practicing until we can do it discreetly."
Reponse: Harry nodded again. "Yeah, sounds like a plan."
title: A Stubbornly Persistent Illusion
author: ChokolatteJedi

Dialogue: "Okay," Hermione nodded. Ron hadn't mentioned that to her, but she didn't doubt Harry's memory.
Reponse: "So it sounds like there are a lot of books on curse breaking, and there might be one that lays out the common reaction combinations or something, instead of you having to cross-reference and make your own list." Harry concluded.
title: A Stubbornly Persistent Illusion
author: ChokolatteJedi

Dialogue: This time it was Hermione who stopped dead in the corridor. Harry also stopped and turned to her apprehensively. Finally Hermione found her voice and she flung herself at Harry in a brief hug. "Harry that's brilliant!"
Reponse: "Er...ehm..." Harry stuttered until Hermione released him.
title: A Stubbornly Persistent Illusion
author: ChokolatteJedi

Dialogue: "Er...ehm..." Harry stuttered until Hermione released him.
Reponse: "You go start your homework," she instructed, already taking a few steps in the other direction. "I'll look for curse breaking books in the library and meet you back there!"
title: A Stubbornly Persistent Illusion
author: ChokolatteJedi

Dialogue: "Why would you want to read about house elves?" Ron asked, not bothering to swallow his mouthful of potatoes first.
Reponse: "Ugh," Hermione scowled at him. "I wanted to learn more about them, Ronald. And it turns out that this book covers all kinds of elvish species, not just house elves."
title: A Stubbornly Persistent Illusion
author: ChokolatteJedi

Dialogue: "Ugh," Hermione scowled at him. "I wanted to learn more about them, Ronald. And it turns out that this book covers all kinds of elvish species, not just house elves."
Reponse: "There are other elves?" Harry perked up. "Like the ones from telly?"
title: A Stubbornly Persistent Illusion
author: ChokolatteJedi

Dialogue: "Wow."
Reponse: "But, starting with house elves, they appear to be like tiny people, right? Not human exactly, but not an animal."
title: A Stubbornly Persistent Illusion
author: ChokolatteJedi

Dialogue: "But, starting with house elves, they appear to be like tiny people, right? Not human exactly, but not an animal."
Reponse: "Right," Harry nodded.
title: A Stubbornly Persistent Illusion
author: ChokolatteJedi

Dialogue: "Well it turns out that they aren't. This is an example of convergent evolution, where they gained features that are similar to a human's, but they don't descend from the same primate evolutionary tree as us."
Reponse: "Huh?" Ron looked completely baffled, and Hermione assumed that evolution was probably one more thing that wizarding children weren't taught, like literature and maths.
title: A Stubbornly Persistent Illusion
author: ChokolatteJedi

Dialogue: "Huh?" Ron looked completely baffled, and Hermione assumed that evolution was probably one more thing that wizarding children weren't taught, like literature and maths.
Reponse: "So they aren't related to monkeys and such?" Harry looked intrigued.
title: A Stubbornly Persistent Illusion
author: ChokolatteJedi

Dialogue: "Did you ever get to symbiosis, parasitism, and mutualism in science?" Hermione asked. She didn't think so - at least not in depth -, since he would have been a year behind her in school, but it was possible.
Reponse: "Uh, symbiotes live together, and parasites are like them, but bad for the host?" Harry said slowly, face screwed up in concentration. "Symbiotes are like a bird that eats bugs that bother cows in return for a meal? And parasites are like fleas and ticks?"
title: A Stubbornly Persistent Illusion
author: ChokolatteJedi

Dialogue: "Uh, symbiotes live together, and parasites are like them, but bad for the host?" Harry said slowly, face screwed up in concentration. "Symbiotes are like a bird that eats bugs that bother cows in return for a meal? And parasites are like fleas and ticks?"
Reponse: "Yes, somewhat," Hermione agreed. "There are degrees to both of those relationships, and there is a category called mutualism. Mutualism means that both parties gain something from the relationship, either in a service sense or a resource sense. Service-resource relationships would include something like a bee that provides a service - pollination - to the plant, in return for a resource - food."
title: A Stubbornly Persistent Illusion
author: ChokolatteJedi

Dialogue: "Got it."
Reponse: "Service-service is trickier, since there is often a resource component as well, but a good example would be a sea anemone that provides a home that protects a clownfish from predators, while the clownfish chases away other fish that would feed on the anemone. Service for service."
title: A Stubbornly Persistent Illusion
author: ChokolatteJedi

Dialogue: "In a way," Hermione agreed. "They provide us service through their magic, which is different from ours. But in return, they feed off of our magic: not in a parasitic way, he made quite clear. Purely in a symbiotic way."
Reponse: "They feed on us?" Harry looked confused.
title: A Stubbornly Persistent Illusion
author: ChokolatteJedi

Dialogue: "They feed on us?" Harry looked confused.
Reponse: "Think of it like this," Hermione used the example from the book. "We humans put off heat. It escapes from our body and goes into the air. We don't do anything with it, and if you invented some kind of machine to absorb that heat from the air around us, it wouldn't negatively impact us at all. Well, all wizards and witches also exude magic. Not a lot, but a little at all times, unless we've severely depleted our magical cores somehow."
title: A Stubbornly Persistent Illusion
author: ChokolatteJedi

Dialogue: "Oh, and house elves feed off of that extra magic?" Harry got it.
Reponse: "Yes! Early house elves just absorbed magic from being near any magic user. They would return the favor by doing little things that they thought would help us. Most fables, like the cobbler's elves and tooth fairy, are examples of that kind of thing. Eventually, they found that formalizing the relationship with a bond produced more magic for the elf, or magic they were better able to collect. Since then, they tend to specialize in assistance magic in a variety of forms, but generally of the domestic chore variety, as that is what human magic users find the most beneficial from them."
title: A Stubbornly Persistent Illusion
author: ChokolatteJedi

Dialogue: "So the elves at Hogwarts are bound to the Headmaster?" Harry asked. "That seems like a lot to ask of one person."
Reponse: "Actually, they are bound, communally, to the community of Hogwarts, with the Headmaster as the bonder," Hermione explained. "There's a whole chapter devoted to communal bonds. The Ministry uses the same set up, as do manufacturers and Quidditch stadiums. They have fewer elves than Hogwarts and the Ministry, obviously, but they use the same kind of communal bond. Apparently at the stadiums, the elves get a little bit from the teams during practice, but basically 'top off' on game days from all the spectators."
title: A Stubbornly Persistent Illusion
author: ChokolatteJedi

Dialogue: "I was just getting to that part," Hermione explained. "But from what I've read so far, my guess is that they would be able to go back to absorbing ambient magic from wizarding communities, like Diagon Alley or Hogsmeade. It wouldn't be as... filling... as if they were bound. But like I said, that's a guess."
Reponse: Harry considered that, then hesitantly said, "Can you... would- when you're finished, can you tell me, or let me read it? I don't want him to be... hurting, or starving, or whatever, because of me."
title: A Stubbornly Persistent Illusion
author: ChokolatteJedi

Dialogue: "Honestly, Ronald," Hermione huffed. "You could at least swallow before speaking. That's disgusting."
Reponse: Ron frowned at her, but actually obeyed before retorting. "You're not my mum."
title: A Stubbornly Persistent Illusion
author: ChokolatteJedi

Dialogue: "That's also quite possible," Hermione agreed. "Next time - if there is a next time,- we need a plan in place. What if I remember that I need to run to the library before I can drink it."
Reponse: "I could remind you that you need to eat," Harry added. That exact thing had happened more than once last year, when Hermione was struggling with her time turner. Looking back, she definitely could have handled that better, especially in terms of setting aside time to sleep and relax.
title: A Stubbornly Persistent Illusion
author: ChokolatteJedi

Dialogue: "I want to look up some recipes," Hermione said, pointing at the book from Dobby. "Why don't you run the charm yourself and see what results you get, then compare notes."
Reponse: "Alright," still looking a little worried, Harry slid into the desk chair and accepted the charts from Hermione.
title: A Stubbornly Persistent Illusion
author: ChokolatteJedi

Dialogue: "And that's more green than yellow, so probably pearl, which is most commonly found in love potions," Harry continued to mutter. "Now speckles means a plant activator, and the size matches a flowering plant, though I suppose it could be a shrub. Not the roots or leaves, so either stems or flowers. Maybe nectar. Hmm.... they're appearing a lot, which leans towards plants in the orchid family. They're also in all sorts of colors... wait... rainbow colors usually means roses or nettles. It could be nettle stem... I'm not seeing the grey, though. Wait, is there brown? Hmmm... That could be? I think it's more orange, though."
Reponse: "Well that's pretty much exactly what I found, though I forgot about the nettle," Hermione said, plonking down her own book. "Now, here's the potion that I think Mrs Weasley used. 'Audaciaffectux is a short-lived potion that strengthens attraction, promotes action, and sparks attention. It is unable to manufacture feelings where none exist, but it can elevate interest to attraction, and attraction to love. Maximum duration two hours."
title: A Stubbornly Persistent Illusion
author: ChokolatteJedi

Dialogue: "Now, being a love potion, you can see it uses the pearl and roses, but it uses thorns instead of petals, and no ashwinder eggs: only robin's eggs to promote courage. We both saw that there was no brown in the speckles, so the potion used on me must use petals instead of thorns."
Reponse: Harry was reading over her arm and pointed at the ingredients, "No orchid either."

Reponse: Finally, she found it. "Gliscor-Amortentia is as strong as its cousin, Amortentia, but it is distinct in that it features a slow-acting component. Whereas drinking Amortentia causes the imbiber to immediately fall in love and act noticeably so, Gliscor-Ardortenstia has little immediate effect. The imbiber will display a more tolerant attitude towards the target, followed by fondness, affection, love, and with continued doses, obsession. Gliscor-Ardortenstia is preferred when an immediate change in attitude would be suspicious, or when a stronger result (due to long term build up) is desired."

Dialogue: She kept reading. "Yes, here it is. When a department head so chosen, one Allois Carrow, was later found to have accepted bribes in direct contraindication of his oath of office, he attempted to claim that he was not bound by the oath because his full name was in fact Adley Allois Carrow. The Goblet of Fire was called to arbitrate, and, matching his signature submitted with his application, stripped him of his magic. From this, it became clear that the Goblet relies, not on the exact wording of the submitted name, as Carrow believed, but on the magical signature submitted."
Reponse: "So it doesn't matter if someone puts my name in the Goblet, as long as I don't cast a spell at it?" Harry stopped pacing.
title: A Stubbornly Persistent Illusion
author: ChokolatteJedi

Dialogue: "Alright, that makes sense." Harry agreed.
Reponse: "Now, the second thing to do is to fight back against the validity of the contract. With wizard-made or goblin-made contracts, your best bet is human error. Or goblin error. If you can prove that they made an error, putting in the wrong name, or including a typo, for example, you have better grounds to have it nullified."
title: A Stubbornly Persistent Illusion

Dialogue: "Now, the second thing to do is to fight back against the validity of the contract. With wizard-made or goblin-made contracts, your best bet is human error. Or goblin error. If you can prove that they made an error, putting in the wrong name, or including a typo, for example, you have better grounds to have it nullified."
Reponse: "With object-made contracts, there is less room to fight, because the object is presumed to be flawless. In your case, our best shot would be to attack the validity of the name submissions and investigate the wards that are designed to keep underaged students from submitting their names. If you can find fault with the selection, or prove that the protections put in place would have stopped you from entering, you have a better chance of protesting your inclusion."
title: A Stubbornly Persistent Illusion
author: ChokolatteJedi

Dialogue: At Merlin's faint smile he knows he does. "'S one of the few times I've seen you and Morgana get along."
Reponse: "Well, she hated Lord Jerlon as much as you did. Humiliating him on the training grounds was as much a service to her as it was for you." Arthur smiles when it makes Merlin giggle. "I think she likes you more than she likes me most days."
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "Well, she hated Lord Jerlon as much as you did. Humiliating him on the training grounds was as much a service to her as it was for you." Arthur smiles when it makes Merlin giggle. "I think she likes you more than she likes me most days."
Reponse: "Like that's hard."
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "Like that's hard."
Reponse: Arthur claps his other shoulder lightly even though he doesn't make an effort to hide his smile. "Clotpole."
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: Arthur claps his other shoulder lightly even though he doesn't make an effort to hide his smile. "Clotpole."
Reponse: "That's my word."
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "That's my word."
Reponse: "And it suits you perfectly."
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "And it suits you perfectly."
Reponse: "Does somebody know?"
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "Does somebody know?"
Reponse: Merlin frowns. "What?"
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: Merlin frowns. "What?"
Reponse: "I'm hurt you won't tell me," Arthur confesses, "but does somebody know what happened?"
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "I'm hurt you won't tell me," Arthur confesses, "but does somebody know what happened?"
Reponse: "I think Sir Leon saw." Merlin lets Arthur turn his head to examine the bruise. It's a nasty thing, already turning Merlin's cheekbone purple. If it'd hit anywhere else, it'd have broken Merlin's nose. "Probably a few others did too."
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "I think Sir Leon saw." Merlin lets Arthur turn his head to examine the bruise. It's a nasty thing, already turning Merlin's cheekbone purple. If it'd hit anywhere else, it'd have broken Merlin's nose. "Probably a few others did too."
Reponse: His eyes narrow. "Are you going to ask him?"
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: His eyes narrow. "Are you going to ask him?"
Reponse: "Someone put their hands on you," Arthur insists, "someone hurt you. Don't you understand?"
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "Someone put their hands on you," Arthur insists, "someone hurt you. Don't you understand?"
Reponse: "Yeah." Merlin ducks his head and lets Arthur pull him close. "Yeah, I do."
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "Yeah." Merlin ducks his head and lets Arthur pull him close. "Yeah, I do."
Reponse: "It's not that big a deal."
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "It's not that big a deal."
Reponse: "It is to me."
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "It is to me."
Reponse: "It's not like I'll get out of helping him too, he's--"
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "It's not like I'll get out of helping him too, he's--"
Reponse: "...he's one of your knights, Arthur. I have to."
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "...he's one of your knights, Arthur. I have to."
Reponse: "You know he's just going to hurt you," Arthur murmurs, clutching Merlin tighter, "don't put yourself through that."
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "You know he's just going to hurt you," Arthur murmurs, clutching Merlin tighter, "don't put yourself through that."
Reponse: "But you like me there when you train."
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "But you like me there when you train."
Reponse: "I do. I also like you unbruised."
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "I do. I also like you unbruised."
Reponse: "Judging by the way you throw things at me, I hadn't noticed."
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "Judging by the way you throw things at me, I hadn't noticed."
Reponse: "I would never," he mutters, staring at Merlin, "ever do something like that to you."
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "I would never," he mutters, staring at Merlin, "ever do something like that to you."
Reponse: "Enter." Arthur keeps one hand on Merlin's shoulder as he turns toward the door.
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "Enter." Arthur keeps one hand on Merlin's shoulder as he turns toward the door.
Reponse: "Oh, you poor thing," she says, "I had hoped Leon was exaggerating."
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "Oh, you poor thing," she says, "I had hoped Leon was exaggerating."
Reponse: "Never, my lady," the knight says, locking eyes with Arthur. "Sire, I assume Merlin has told you?"
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "Never, my lady," the knight says, locking eyes with Arthur. "Sire, I assume Merlin has told you?"
Reponse: Arthur glances at Merlin who's reassuring Morgana he's alright. "Not exactly."
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: Arthur glances at Merlin who's reassuring Morgana he's alright. "Not exactly."
Reponse: "Tell me, Arthur," she says icily, "is it common practice to strike sparring partners across the face with a staff when they aren't wearing a helmet?"
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "Tell me, Arthur," she says icily, "is it common practice to strike sparring partners across the face with a staff when they aren't wearing a helmet?"
Reponse: "No," Arthur growls, "no it is not."
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "No," Arthur growls, "no it is not."
Reponse: "In that case, I believe Sir Tordwin requires further instruction."
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "In that case, I believe Sir Tordwin requires further instruction."
Reponse: "Merlin," Morgana says, drawing Arthur's attention back to the pair, "I think I'm going to join them tomorrow. Won't you come to help me?"
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "Merlin," Morgana says, drawing Arthur's attention back to the pair, "I think I'm going to join them tomorrow. Won't you come to help me?"
Reponse: Arthur stops Merlin from picking up the basket. "You're mine, Merlin," he murmurs, stroking Merlin's cheek, "in whatever way you choose to be. That means I protect you."
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: Arthur stops Merlin from picking up the basket. "You're mine, Merlin," he murmurs, stroking Merlin's cheek, "in whatever way you choose to be. That means I protect you."
Reponse: "He won't touch you again. None of them will."
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "He won't touch you again. None of them will."
Reponse: "I know."
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "I know."
Reponse: "Now, I'm sure there are better things for me to do."
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "Now, I'm sure there are better things for me to do."
Reponse: "Prat."
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "Prat."
Reponse: "Clotpole."
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "Clotpole."
Reponse: "Dollophead."
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "Dollophead."
Reponse: "Merlin!"
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: "Merlin!"
Reponse: "Arthur."
title: Not a Normal Servant
author: TheAsexualofSpades

Dialogue: Merlin should probably be afraid. He's not. Really, he's annoyed more than anything. "Your ribs, sire," he states in hushed tones, chiding Arthur as he always does. "I said I'd take care of this. You need to rest."
Reponse: "Heal me then, if it bothers you so." Arthur responds, just a second too late to sound properly bossy.
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: Merlin winces. "... I'm no good at healing spells," he answers, looking down. He remembers Uther, and how ever since, he's doubted his own magic when it comes to mending wounds or ills. "Please go back to Gaius. I'd rather you not see this."
Reponse: But as stubborn as always, Arthur shakes his head. "What kind of King would I be if I let you take back my castle and didn't even send someone to watch your back? What's the plan?"
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: And Arthur just nods, tightening his jaw as he refocuses. "... the dragon might take too long once they notice us. Let's just go with the lightning. Can you ensure I don't get hit?"
Reponse: Merlin looks over him thoughtfully for a moment, then nods. "I can cast an enchantment on your armor. It will repel the effects of weather."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "... did it work?"
Reponse: Merlin smiles to himself. "Yes. Let's move to the other end of the courtyard, I'll start calling the storm. They should be past the gate by the time I finish."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: Arthur sighs, re-drawing his sword. "And so are you."
Reponse: Her hand lifts, stepping back to give herself room. "You won't live to regret those words. You think Merlin can save you? I know who will defeat me, and it isn't a nobody like him."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "No--" Merlin winces as he accidentally shifts the slashed skin of his arm. He's starting to feel dizzy... hopefully Arthur brings Gaius to see him. "I can return it. Should I?"
Reponse: "Will she regain her magic?" Arthur asks, because it's a legitimate question. His King knows so little about Sorcery.
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: Merlin shakes his head. "I bound it. She can't use it at all, voice or no."
Reponse: "Return her voice." Arthur orders, then as Merlin opens his mouth, holds his hand up to tell him to wait. "Unless you aren't able to. You look worn out."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "Hell of a place to test that theory," Arthur comments, but his tone is hard to read. Merlin doesn't like it; he's come to know Arthur so well, it sets him on edge to be unable to read him now.
Reponse: "You have been known to call me an idiot, sire," Merlin reminds him, hoping the levity helps his case. His half-smile is gone before he continues. "I used magic to save you from the old woman," he admits quietly. The first confession of many to come. "I don't even know what I did. I just saw you were in danger, and my magic responded. When Uther turned to me, I was so scared, I thought he'd seen even though I hadn't used any spells."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "You'll bleed out."
Reponse: Merlin hesitates, swallowing nervously as he tries and fails to read Arthur's expression. "... will it matter?"
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: And that-- that gets a flash of emotion from Arthur. He looks scared-- worried. And then it's gone, and his expression is hardened again. "Stop being dramatic, Merlin. Get up, I'm taking you to Gaius."
Reponse: "Don't get ahead of yourself. I haven't decided what to do with you," Arthur explains, giving a small sigh. "But I don't want you dying while I figure it out. Come on."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: Morgana lets out a noise of disgust. "What, need time to decide whether his head rolls or he burns, Arthur?"
Reponse: But rather than brush her off, or ignore her comment, Arthur rounds on his half-sister, eyes ablaze. "You have no right." He says, voice cold as ice. "Merlin has just saved this kingdom and everyone in it. He's saved my life gods know how many more times than that. This is the first time I've ever seen Magic used for anything other than to harm my family and my people... to this extent. So no, I do not know what I am going to do right now, because Merlin poses a question that I have not yet had to ask."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: Merlin nods at the order, briefly closing his eyes. "My intentions to heal your father were sincere. I searched for a strong enough spell, and found only one. To my knowledge, it was a healing spell that would save your father's life." He pauses, bowing his head sadly. "I failed to notice the enchanted charm placed around his neck, which reversed the effects of my spell. What was meant to heal, instead harmed him. I do not know for certain who placed the reversal charm, though in light of recent events, I suspect Agravaine is responsible, under Morgana's direction."
Reponse: "And for the death of the sorceress Morgause, how do you plead?"
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: He stands, continuing his speech. "It is difficult to define what a traitor is. If it was not so, then surely we might have seen Agravaine's betrayal much sooner. Or Morgana's, even. But I think, we can all agree on what a traitor not. A traitor is not loyal, to the point of drinking poison for his prince's safety. A traitor is not a man who repeatedly risks his own safety, breaking a law that could have him killed, all to protect the very people who would have him killed for it. A traitor does not go unarmed and unarmored to face down a dragon, with no guarantee of returning."
Reponse: Now, Arthur's eyes fall back on Merlin, watching him carefully. "Merlin is many things, but he is not a traitor. He broke our laws, but he committed no treason. And now I ask, if such a thing is possible, should the man be punished, or should the law be changed?"
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: The King seats himself once more, looking now to his left. "Does anyone disagree?"
Reponse: Arthur throws him an exasperated look. "... Merlin?"
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "I don't want to throw out everything you just said, sire, because you are mostly right, of course." He smiles as the look of irritation grows on Arthur's face. "But there's a certain practicing of Magic called the Dark Arts. And they are... definitely evil. That should stay banned."
Reponse: Arthur looks only mildly less annoyed at this. "And have you practiced these dark arts?"
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: Instead, Arthur smiles in a somewhat vicious way. "I think probation until the laws are changed is in order. However, Merlin here did just save most of Camelot nearly single-handed. I do think that calls for a reward."
Reponse: As soon as Merlin hears it, he knows it's going to be bad. He starts to shake his head. "Oh no, sire, I couldn't possibly--"
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: Arthur grins even more vindictively. "He will be given an elevated position in the royal household. Welcome our new court-appointed sorcerer."
Reponse: Merlin bites back a groan, looking downright miserable. "You're as bad as your father," he accuses lightly. "Thanks for saving us, Merlin! Here's a job you don't want!" His tone is a mockery of the late king.
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: Merlin bites back a groan, looking downright miserable. "You're as bad as your father," he accuses lightly. "Thanks for saving us, Merlin! Here's a job you don't want!" His tone is a mockery of the late king.
Reponse: "Be grateful That's all I inflict on you, Merlin," Arthur threatens, standing. "Dismissed."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "Don't you dare," Merlin hisses, much to Arthur's amusement. "All that responsibility, no thank you. I've got my hands full keeping you alive."
Reponse: The King continues to laugh, smiling quietly to himself once he wears himself out. He takes on a more solemn tone when he continues. "Before we left to search for Balinor... I did what I could to find any record of him in the library. It turns out that... the title 'dragonlord' was not merely honorific. Each of the dragonlords were nobles, with their own keeps or castles. Your father's wasn't far from here. It's yours, if you want it."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "We'll ride out as soon as I've decided what to do with Morgana and my Uncle," Arthur promises.
Reponse: That's more than fair. Merlin nods, flashing his friend a small, genuine smile. "... Thank you. Really. I didn't expect you to do all this for me."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: That's more than fair. Merlin nods, flashing his friend a small, genuine smile. "... Thank you. Really. I didn't expect you to do all this for me."
Reponse: "It's only right," Arthur says, just as quiet and sincere. "You've done more for me than anyone in this kingdom. Any knight, any noble, any servant. You're the only person I am sure that I can trust. I can't lose you, not over this." He puts his hand on Merlin's shoulder, stopping in the middle of the hallway to face him. "Not over magic you were born with... not when you came to Camelot to tame your magic and make it safe. I give you a hard time, Merlin, but you really are my only and truest friend. I'd change every law in Camelot if it kept you by my side."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: And that catches Arthur's attention. Merlin worries briefly that Arthur might be frightened by the example of his power, but instead his friend just looks interested. "You can use your magic to repair the castle?"
Reponse: Merlin nods, eager to use his magic to help. "Do you want to see?" It'd be nice to show Arthur more of the benevolent uses of Magic, rather than just the kind that's useful in battle.
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: Arthur whistles, kneeling down to support Merlin. "I thought you'd just fix the wall. Not... all of it."
Reponse: Merlin laughs softly, leaning on his friend's shoulder. "You should have specified."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "I'm not sweating," Merlin points out, grinning back at Arthur. His friend helps him back to his feet, and the dizziness fades somewhat.
Reponse: "Camelot hasn't looked like this since I was young." Arthur is silent for another moment, just admiring the view before him and the many stunned, excited people chattering below. He pulls away to let Merlin stand on his own. "I better get you fed before you keel over, oh great and powerful sorcerer."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "... I'll have some food sent your way, Merlin." The King tells him, frowning softly as he looks Merlin up and down. "You should get some more rest. Tomorrow will be an exciting day. I'll make my announcement about you and about magic at noon."
Reponse: Merlin nods, reluctant to part with Arthur, but knowing that after this attack, his king has many things to attend to, most of which don't involve him. "Shall I write your speech for you, sire? One more time?"
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "Oh, don't worry about Merlin, princess. I'll make sure he has some fun."
Reponse: Arthur looks at them both a bit dubiously. "Why am I more worried now?" He mutters under his breath, then shakes his head. "Fine. Sir Gwaine, keep Merlin and yourself out of trouble. He just repaired my entire castle, so don't let him do any servant work."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: Arthur looks at them both a bit dubiously. "Why am I more worried now?" He mutters under his breath, then shakes his head. "Fine. Sir Gwaine, keep Merlin and yourself out of trouble. He just repaired my entire castle, so don't let him do any servant work."
Reponse: "Out of trouble and into the Tavern, sire," Gwaine says agreeably, pulling twin sighs from Merlin and Arthur. Two sides of the same coin, indeed.
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "Oh, don't worry about Merlin, princess. I'll make sure he has some fun."
Reponse: Arthur looks at them both a bit dubiously. "Why am I more worried now?" He mutters under his breath, then shakes his head. "Fine. Sir Gwaine, keep Merlin and yourself out of trouble. He just repaired my entire castle, so don't let him do any servant work."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: Arthur looks at them both a bit dubiously. "Why am I more worried now?" He mutters under his breath, then shakes his head. "Fine. Sir Gwaine, keep Merlin and yourself out of trouble. He just repaired my entire castle, so don't let him do any servant work."
Reponse: "Out of trouble and into the Tavern, sire," Gwaine says agreeably, pulling twin sighs from Merlin and Arthur. Two sides of the same coin, indeed.
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "Not that I'm disagreeing with you, sire," Merlin calls to him, teasing. "But why do you say that?"
Reponse: Arthur spins again, sighing heavily. "The man told me I would need Courage, Strength, and Magic on my quest. Then he called me Courage. Then you two showed up to help." He points at himself. "Courage," he points at Gwaine, "Strength, apparently," and then he points to Merlin, "Magic. It was so obvious, he might as well have bloody told me you were a sorcerer. You certainly weren't going to be Strength."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "Sire, are you alright?"
Reponse: "I am," he answers with a sigh. "Just realizing again what a true friend you are, Merlin. I am glad Destiny decided to make you the other half of my coin." He tosses in a tease, knowing how Merlin feels about that particular analogy.
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "Love you too, Sire," Merlin responds, teasing him as easily as breathing.
Reponse: Arthur snorts, and does not deny it. "Goodbye, gentlemen."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "Love you too, Sire," Merlin responds, teasing him as easily as breathing.
Reponse: Arthur snorts, and does not deny it. "Goodbye, gentlemen."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: Merlin feels bad. He's instantly guilt-ridden, looking down at his feet. "It's not that I didn't trust you, Gwaine. I wanted to tell you, so many times. I knew you'd keep my secret."
Reponse: "So why didn't you?" Gwaine asks, and Merlin can tell that he's trying not to sound accusing. He is feeling betrayed, not because Merlin is a sorcerer, but because he kept it from him.
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "So why didn't you?" Gwaine asks, and Merlin can tell that he's trying not to sound accusing. He is feeling betrayed, not because Merlin is a sorcerer, but because he kept it from him.
Reponse: "Because Will knew, and Lancelot knew, and I saw what it did to them. Both of them died, protecting me and taking my secret to their graves, and I... I didn't want to lose you too, Gwaine. I didn't want to burden you like I did them." He sees both of them in Gwaine. Both his closest friends; Will's callous nature and disdain for nobility, Lancelot's drive to protect those who cannot protect themselves and his boundless loyalty.
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "Yes, my lord?"
Reponse: Arthur takes a deep breath. He stares up at his sorcerer, hand on his sword. "Merlin, do you notice anything amiss, by chance?"
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: Arthur thinks he should be applauded for not fainting at the sight. "Hello," he says back, because what else is he supposed to do?
Reponse: Merlin grins as if Arthur has just made his day. "See! He's an okay dragon, really. He doesn't always burn kingdoms down."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "Merlin," he says, as kindly as he can manage. "Please send the dragon home. He's terrifying the townsfolk."
Reponse: Merlin pouts. "But--"
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "Oh no," Merlin says, in a voice like a mouse.
Reponse: He looks at Arthur, then at his dragon. "Kilgharrah, I am so, so sorry. Arthur, I don't-- I-- um."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: Merlin swallows guiltily, and Arthur decides to take pity on him. "You and I will have words later. For now, just tell Kil-- er-- Kilgharrah? Tell him he can go home."
Reponse: "Yes, sire." His sorcerer looks properly ashamed of himself, at least. The dragonlord looks up at the great golden dragon, and says a few soft words in a harsh language Arthur is certain he could never replicate.
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "Yes, sire." His sorcerer looks properly ashamed of himself, at least. The dragonlord looks up at the great golden dragon, and says a few soft words in a harsh language Arthur is certain he could never replicate.
Reponse: The dragon bows to Merlin as well, once he is done speaking. "Good luck, young warlock," Kilgharrah says with laughter in his voice. "If you will take some advice before I go, Merlin... it is best not to let yourself make these sorts of mistakes. You are immortal, and I will live for many centuries to come. My kind has a long memory."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "What were you thinking-- nevermind, clearly you weren't. Gods." Arthur curses, taking a second to reign in his temper. "Get out of my sight. Go spend a night in a cell and think about your actions."
Reponse: "... is that all?"
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "Help me understand, Merlin. You are said to be powerful-- the most powerful sorcerer to ever live. You are said to be the man destined to bring magic back to Albion. Why take Arthur's side? Why not kill him, and take the throne yourself? No one could stop you."
Reponse: "Free my magic, Merlin," she says, a desperate note entering her voice. "You and I... we were close, before. I know why you didn't tell me about your magic; you were afraid, like I was. I would have protected you back then... Arthur wouldn't have. Free me. We can rule together, Merlin. No one is a match for us."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "How can you say such a thing?!" She shrieks, high-pitched and full of twisted rage, burning hatred. "You went though exactly what I did! You've seen Uther and Arthur murder our kind in cold blood! They must pay for it with their own! How can you have lived under their reign of terror and take their side?!"
Reponse: "Arthur's side," he corrects her, as calm as she is vicious. "Albion's side. I see a future where there is magic and peace, and in it, Arthur is king." He closes his eyes, trying to visualize it for himself.
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "... then please, Merlin... show me kindness now. Free my magic. I am nothing without it. I'm so cold, and empty, defenseless."
Reponse: "I can't do that, Morgana," he says to her, lacking his former coldness. "You have hurt too many people. If Arthur lets you live tomorrow, and he very well might... then perhaps someday, you can earn it back. If you can let go of your vengeance, if you can find peace... I will be happy to give your magic back to you."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "Please," she whispers. "I'm nothing... nothing on my own."
Reponse: "That isn't true," he responds, turning to face her more fully. "The Morgana I believed could do no wrong, the kind Lady I knew as a friend... she knew nothing of magic. And she was the brightest light in all of Camelot. You were so much more than what you've become."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: After a short hesitation, he decides to tell her the truth. "... Gwaine took me out drinking, and I summoned the Great Dragon to Camelot. He didn't hurt anyone, but he scared quite a few, so Arthur sent us to spend a night down here to cool our heads."
Reponse: Startled laughter sounds from her cell. "... you don't seem drunk now."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: The King in question is approaching now, and Merlin turns his frown towards him, speaking loud enough for Arthur to hear what he says to George. "Anyways, I told him I didn't want a promotion, so if he misses me, he only has himself to blame."
Reponse: The blond scowls at him, responding even though he wasn't addressed. "Miss you? Why would I miss your terrible service, Merlin? George here actually does all his chores, in a quality and timely manner."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: The blond scowls at him, responding even though he wasn't addressed. "Miss you? Why would I miss your terrible service, Merlin? George here actually does all his chores, in a quality and timely manner."
Reponse: Merlin nods indulgently. "And he tells terrific jokes, I've heard. George, tell us a joke, will you?"
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "Hey- that's my word!" Merlin protests, which only gets him a teasing grin in response. To get Arthur back, he throws in a wicked smile of his own. "It could be worse, I could... take him in as my apprentice. Teach him the wily ways of sorcery and insulting prats."
Reponse: Arthur points at him, blue eyes narrowed. "If you do, I'll throw you in the stocks. Do not teach that man magic, he's already too scarily efficient as it is. I'm serious."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "Merlin..."
Reponse: "I've gone to the stocks for less," Merlin points out.
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: Now the prince looks desperate. "Don't do it. If you... if you teach him magic, I shall give him your job as Court Sorcerer. Then what?"
Reponse: A slow grin makes its way across Merlin's face. "The job I didn't want? Great! Then I can go back to just being Gaius's apprentice Physician, like I was bloody supposed to in the first place."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: Merlin is stirring the stew when Arthur finally comments on it. "Why don't you just use Magic? Surely it would be faster?"
Reponse: His question gives the sorcerer pause. Merlin sits back on his heels, not taking his eyes off his cooking. "Habit, I suppose? It's not very hard or time-consuming to feed the horses and cook by hand, anyways."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: Merlin pokes at the fire a bit, then starts spooning portions of stew out for them in their travel bowls. "Just something Kilgharrah said." He takes a moment to answer.
Reponse: "Clear as mud," Arthur says when he doesn't elaborate immediately, earning a wan smile from his friend.
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "Clear as mud," Arthur says when he doesn't elaborate immediately, earning a wan smile from his friend.
Reponse: Merlin hands him his stew before continuing with his explanation. "I don't know for certain, but... that name the Druids give me, Emrys... it means immortal. And there are... things I can't explain. Poisons and venoms I've survived with no antidote. The Dorocha that failed to take my life... I don't think I can die. At least, not by mortal means."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: But Merlin only shrugs. "No idea. I expect it'll be a while, if I have to be immortal for it."
Reponse: "And I'm to... die, and then reincarnate when I'm needed again?" Arthur shakes his head. "Sounds like a load of rubbish. Why not just make me immortal too? Or why not have us both come back when we're needed?"
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "I'll ensure you have a few hours of free time a week to do so," Arthur interjects with a promise. He feels a bit guilty for never noticing. "I didn't know, otherwise I'd have assigned you a tutor. Your knighthood is my responsibility, and I should have made sure you didn't feel ashamed for any lack of knowledge. Do you know if any of the others need tutoring?"
Reponse: Merlin chews his lip. "I know Gwen was teaching Elyan... but I'm not sure if she was able to... finish teaching." He stops, awkwardly avoiding the subject of Arthur's banishment of his fiancee.
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: Merlin fixes him with a kind look, smiling softly at him in the low light from the fire at their feet. "I thought as much, but wasn't sure. Thank you for clarifying, my lord."
Reponse: "Just call me Arthur," the king insists, heart suddenly aching at the distance of formalities. "You are my closest friend, Merlin. There is no need for titles between us."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: Arthur looks over at him, the blue in his eyes highlighted by the magical light floating nearby. He looks over Merlin, watching him with a critical eye. "... you can't run from responsibility, Merlin. The druids call you their King. You have a duty to them, to protect and guide them."
Reponse: "My duty is to protect you, Arthur." And that's all. That's all he's willing to give his life up for. To live an eternity for. Arthur, the one and only King he will ever pledge himself to.
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: Arthur stops him, a heavy hand gripping his shoulder. "No, Merlin." The King's voice is hard, brooking no room for argument. "That isn't what the prophesy says. It says that we, together, will unite and build the golden age of Albion. Not that you keep me alive until I can do it myself."
Reponse: Merlin refuses to look at him. "I'm not a King."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "Really not the time, Merlin!" Arthur calls back to him, letting his annoyance bleed into his tone.
Reponse: "I'm having fun!" Gwaine shouts back with a boisterous laugh, heading over to help Arthur by outright punching the lights out of one of his dance partners. "Haven't had a proper brawl like this in ages!"
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "See?" Merlin calls back to his king, eyes flashing gold once more as he redirects an arrow into a tree trunk with a bemused smile. Insolent, disobedient, treasonous sorcerer.
Reponse: Percival knocks two men's heads together. "I'm with Arthur, Merlin. We are only three, there are many of them. We'll tire before we defeat them all." He doesn't shout, he doesn't need to. His voice is just deep enough to carry through the sounds of battle to each of them.
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: Arthur is fighting someone, and can't hear Merlin's sigh and he doesn't see his eye roll, but he knows they happen all the same. "Very well-"
Reponse: The rest of his response is cut off by a cry from one of the bandits. "Sorcerer!"
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "But I've thrown plenty of things at you and they've hit," Arthur says. He isn't proud of that, but it doesn't seem to fit what Merlin is saying.
Reponse: Rather than argue, Merlin nods as if Arthur has caught on to his point. "Exactly. I have to consciously tell my magic not to defend me or stop things from falling or whatever else it might do on a whim, all the time. And when I'm constantly splitting my focus between whatever I'm doing and keeping my magic from doing things randomly..."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: The King frowns softly at his friend. "So when you fought just now, you weren't holding your magic back. That's why some of the attacks just glanced away from you, and some just stopped mid-swing?"
Reponse: Merlin nods, seeming relieved that Arthur understands. "It's not such a problem when I have chances to intentionally use my magic. It's just, there's so much of it, and it constantly wants to get out and do things, and I obviously can't let it or I'd have been caught. Even now, a lot of people are still scared of magic and I don't want to frighten anyone." The mage sighs, adjusting his neckerchief. "When I do big spells, like fixing the castle, it's usually fine for a day or so afterwards without me having to hold it all back. But it seems like the more powerful magic I learn and use, the more excess there is when I recover, and the harder it is to keep any of it in. When I don't have any other way to spend it, sometimes I just sneak out to the woods and pour it all into making the trees and flowers grow."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "... You don't have to do that for us," Arthur finally says, placing a hand on Merlin's scrawny shoulder. "Not around me, and not around the Knights. At least, Gwaine, Leon, and Percival won't mind, I'm sure. And I, for one, want to get used to your magic."
Reponse: Merlin looks unsure, pulling his lower lip between his teeth. "I... even Gaius finds it unnerving. I'm not sure that's a good idea... you must already think I'm strange enough."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: Merlin looks away, radiating shame. "... I'm sorry I didn't tell you about her. It slipped my mind."
Reponse: "A whole dragon?" Arthur asks dryly. He doesn't believe it. "We said no more secrets, Merlin."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "No," Arthur says, but it's more disbelief than denial.
Reponse: Merlin looks to the young dragon, shoulders set stubbornly. "I am a dragonlord, and she is the last of her kind. It's my duty to protect her. I saved the egg, and I hatched her."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: Merlin looks to the young dragon, shoulders set stubbornly. "I am a dragonlord, and she is the last of her kind. It's my duty to protect her. I saved the egg, and I hatched her."
Reponse: "You weren't going to tell me," Arthur accuses, frowning. It's less of a question than it is a statement. He knows Merlin's tells.
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "It seems she's formed a bond with you," Merlin says, and doesn't sound pleased by it. He turns to Arthur, then. "I can order her away, if you'd like. I didn't know about this."
Reponse: "I believe you," Arthur finds himself saying, but he's not paying very close attention. His focus is more on Morgana, and her attitude towards the dragon. She seems... different somehow. More like her old self.
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "I'm sorry," he says, and is as surprised as she is to find that the apology is genuine. "It brings me no joy to confine you, Morgana. You were my sister, even before I knew of our blood relation."
Reponse: "Then free me," she pleads, eyes wide. "Merlin told me you are repealing the ban on Magic. That's all I wanted."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "I wish you had come to me," he says suddenly, looking upon her with sadness. "I would have helped you, you know. I could never hate you for how you were born, Morgana. Not for your parentage, and not for your magic, either."
Reponse: He turns to Merlin, then. "I wish both of you had come to me. If I'd known what my father's actions had wrought... if I knew the kind of fear he instilled, even in the closest of my friends and family... had I known, so much bloodshed and strife might've been avoided."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "What are you saying?" Arthur asks, trying to keep the note of hope out of his voice.
Reponse: "I'm saying that Morgana's soul is not yet lost," Merlin tells him, though his tone is hesitant. "She hasn't been initiated as a High Priestess of the Old Religion. I'm saying that she's healing, and should you give her the chance to heal fully, in time, she may be herself again, and I may even be able to restore her magic to her, and teach her to use it safely. I can't decide whether you should give her that chance or not, sire, but if you do, I am willing to take responsibility for her rehabilitation. It may take months, possibly years. The damage was not done overnight and it won't be undone so quickly. But I believe it is possible."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "- and you are a dragonlord. And the king of magic or something. It'd be good for you to take care of her, learn some hands-on responsibility. And maybe it'll help my kingdom get a bit more used to dealing with magic and magical creatures."
Reponse: "... you're really going to let me raise a dragon in Camelot?" Merlin asks, his brows raising to Gaius-levels.
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "If I didn't know any better, I might think he's enchanted you, brother."
Reponse: "... Not with magic," he answers after a moment, thinking that Kilgarrah would probably be proud of such a cryptic response. He stands up and rights the stool. "... I must go. I'll consider all we said before your trial tomorrow. If you think of anything else to help your case, be sure to mention it then. I will hear your side out, Morgana. Our father is dead, his ghost should not hold the power to keep us at odds with one another."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "They're more dignified than your neckerchiefs," Arthur agrees, pleased. "I expect you to wear something new to the council meeting tomorrow. I want to get this revision to the law finalized and put into effect."
Reponse: "I'm joining the council tomorrow?" Merlin asks, intimidated. "As... part of it?"
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: Arthur sighs, approaching the bed and crouching next to it to talk to his friend. "I know it seems like a big change. Just think of it this way, Merlin. You get to talk back to me like you always do, but now I'm actually supposed to listen to you."
Reponse: "So really, nothing has changed," Arthur persists. "I have always valued your counsel. Only now, you get to sit down and speak your mind, rather than doing it between chores and running around the castle."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: It's as good as a love declaration in return, and Arthur feels a knot of stress uncoil from his heart. "Gwyneviere did have my heart," he admits honestly. "But just as she loved Lancelot first and foremost, my heart did not belong to her first. I was... selfish, thinking I could have both of you beside me. Perhaps I deserved her betrayal."
Reponse: "No," Merlin protests in a whisper, holding him tighter.
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "So something can come of it?" Merlin asks, a note of cautious hope in his voice. The candles in the room grow brighter.
Reponse: "Something can," Arthur confirms, kissing him again. This time is softer, just a gentle press of lips to lips, a promise. "I'll need Gaius's blessing to woo you of course--" he grins as Merlin slaps his arm, "but if all goes well, a marriage between us would show people both magical and nonmagical that we are committed to mending the wounds my father wrought. It would show your people that I am not like my father, and it would show mine that Magic is to be accepted without contest."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "Something can," Arthur confirms, kissing him again. This time is softer, just a gentle press of lips to lips, a promise. "I'll need Gaius's blessing to woo you of course--" he grins as Merlin slaps his arm, "but if all goes well, a marriage between us would show people both magical and nonmagical that we are committed to mending the wounds my father wrought. It would show your people that I am not like my father, and it would show mine that Magic is to be accepted without contest."
Reponse: "And what of an heir?" Merlin asks, still looking worried. "Won't you still need one?"
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "And what of an heir?" Merlin asks, still looking worried. "Won't you still need one?"
Reponse: "I can take on a ward," Arthur says, smiling at the concern in Merlin's eyes. "Or if Morgana or Agravaine ever have children, they can be our successor. It's not unheard of... But that's only if it's even necessary. You are immortal, are you not?"
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "I do hope I won't live forever," Merlin responds, initiating a third kiss, light and quick. "I wish to join you in Avalon once our destiny is fulfilled."
Reponse: "And I hope to meet you there as well," Arthur admits quietly.
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "Maybe. I don't know for certain." Merlin hedges. "Worth a try, if I can find the spell for it. One of us would have to be alright with being transformed for nearly a year, though."
Reponse: "Well, you're already a girl, Merlin--" Arthur teases, but breaks off into a grin at Merlin's annoyed look. "We'll discuss it again if we get to that point. We have to worry about the actual courting and marriage first. Which means you need to start being a King to your people sooner than later."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "- sure it does. I said so, and I am the King, Merlin."
Reponse: "You know you can't use that on me when I'm a King too, right?"
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: He can't quite keep the sorrow out of his tone, however. "Ward of King Uther, daughter of Vivienne and Gorlois, my half-sister. You stand before us today accused of treason, multiple counts of attempted regicide, the use of black magic, and murder. How do you plead?"
Reponse: She stands tall before him, unflinching and unafraid. "I am only guilty of fighting for a world where myself, and people like me, can live free and unafraid."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: She nods, her eyes sliding from him to Merlin. "When I discovered I had magic, I was so frightened that Uther would find out. I hadn't chosen it, or sought it out, but I knew he would burn me all the same." She pauses, and the room shifts uncomfortably at the truth in her words.
Reponse: Her eyes return to Arthur as she continues.  "Merlin was the first to know I had Magic, and the first to accept that that is what it was. He tried to help me get away to a druid camp, so they could explain it to me, tell me if I was a monster or not, and-- I hoped-- help me learn to control and hide it." Her words ring out clear and true, and Arthur can sense Merlin's approval from just behind him. "You should remember, Arthur. Uther believed I had been kidnapped when I ran away, and sent you to hunt me down. You tracked Merlin to find me, when he came to beg me to return to Camelot, because Uther was slaughtering anyone who had so much as thrown magic a sideways glance."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "Stand." She does, her own face a mask to hide her fears. "You are my sister, Morgana. It brings me no pleasure to be against you."
Reponse: "Nor I you, brother." She answers, her voice wavering with just a fraction of the fear she must feel.
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "It would bring me no happiness to see you dead, despite all you have done." He admits, for the crowd moreso than her. "Our family has suffered enough bloodshed."
Reponse: The witch nods, regret showing in her eyes. "I see now that spilling more blood will not bring back those Uther killed in his crusade against magic. I should never have extended my hatred and fear of him to you."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: With permission, Arthur faces the council again. Might as well get this sorted out first. "Merlin is a dragonlord. The last dragonlord. His Father was Balinor, and in the days before the purge, he was a nobleman. Upon Balinor's death, Merlin inherited his ability to command dragons, proving his lineage."
Reponse: "The dragonlords were stripped of their titles and land!" The same councilman protests, and Arthur has half a mind to throw him out of the room.
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: After a moment, Sir Leon steps forward. "I... would also like to vouch for Lady Morgana. She was a good friend, a kind soul. I knew her for many years, grew up alongside her, and I sorely miss her. If my King believes she can be redeemed, then so do I."
Reponse: A second later, Elyan steps forward. "My sister would vouch, so I will in her place. Gwen spoke so highly of Lady Morgana. I know she would want to give her a chance to come back to us."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "Thank you both," Morgana says once they're well on their way to her old rooms, and out of anyone else's earshot. "I feared I would not live to see another day."
Reponse: "I am glad this went the way it did," Arthur admits, releasing a slow breath of relief. "You certainly helped, with your speech."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "I am glad this went the way it did," Arthur admits, releasing a slow breath of relief. "You certainly helped, with your speech."
Reponse: Morgana gives him a smile. "I do mean it, you know. I've been meaning to say..." Her countenance takes on a more sombre look. "My magic is bound from me, but it seems my visions are not part of that. I still dream of the future. However, since my capture and the change in the law... they've been... better. Good things. The future with you as king is bright, brother."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "That I wasn't born with it? But I didn't seek it out..."
Reponse: "He told me once that seers are born with the gift of foretelling dreams... and that it's close enough to witchcraft that Uther wouldn't see it as different. It isn't necessarily the same thing, but generally speaking, seers have a predisposition towards sorcery. I think he hoped that by not exposing you to magic, it would only ever be the dreams, and you wouldn't have to fear Uther."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "He told me once that seers are born with the gift of foretelling dreams... and that it's close enough to witchcraft that Uther wouldn't see it as different. It isn't necessarily the same thing, but generally speaking, seers have a predisposition towards sorcery. I think he hoped that by not exposing you to magic, it would only ever be the dreams, and you wouldn't have to fear Uther."
Reponse: Morgana hums, giving a small nod. "It seems I need to apologize to Gaius, too..."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: Merlin offers him an equally helpless look to the one that must be on his own face. As soon as she's gone though, that look morphs into a wide grin; the kind that reaches his cheeks and makes his ears stick out further. "See something you like?" He teases, and Arthur bemoans the fact that all sorcerers apparently have an innate ability to taunt him mercilessly. Does magic only choose people who like to bully Arthur? That would explain so much.
Reponse: "Yes," he answers bluntly, then checks the halls to make sure they're alone before he grabs that bright red scarf and drags Merlin down for a kiss by it. The warlock melts into it, apparently as eager for this as Arthur has been all day.
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: Arthur growls against Merlin's pulse, nipping at his collarbone. "You can touch now," he says, and it's more of an order than a suggestion.
Reponse: "Not here, Arthur," he points out sadly. Arthur knows he's right, as much as he wants to argue. "And not now." Those blue eyes hold so much sadness, so much regret. "We must wait, as you said. Until I can be king."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "I know," he grouses after a moment. "I hate it, though. I would schedule our wedding for next week if I could."
Reponse: "I haven't even said yes yet," Merlin reminds him with a gentle laugh. "You haven't asked me, Arthur."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "It's bad luck to cry at your wedding," Merlin tells him in that same soft, low tone.
Reponse: "I'm sure you'll protect me from it," Arthur returns, admiring his soon-to-be husband.
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: Geoffrey moves on, now that he once more has their full attention. "Do you, King Arthur of Camelot, take unto thyself as husband the fair King Merlin of the Druids and pledge unto him before the triple goddess and these witnesses to be his protector, defender and sure resort, to honor and sustain him, in sickness and in health, in fair and in foul, with all thy worldly powers, to cherish and forsaking all others, keep thee only unto him, so long as ye both shall live?"
Reponse: Arthur looks directly into Merlin's eyes as they listen, smiling softly at his fiancee. "I will."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "Once for luck," they kiss quickly.
Reponse: "Twice for Love," This kiss lasts a bit longer, neither one of them eager to part.
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "... and Thrice for Long life." This kiss lasts the longest, and Geoffrey starts speaking again before they're quite done with it.
Reponse: "By the Power Vested in me by the Realm, I now pronounce you Kings Arthur and Merlin Pendragon, Husband and Husband, sovereign rulers of Camelot and the Druidic peoples."
title: Let us take back the Castle now, and you can behead me later, Sire.
author: coldishcase

Dialogue: "WHAT IS HAPPENING?"
Reponse: "Stop yelling, dude, I'm hungover!"
